Context: Nod2-deficient (Nod2e/e) mice had an inherently altered skin microbiome compared with wild-type controls.

Furthermore, we found that Nod2e/e skin microbiome dominated and caused impaired healing, shown in cross-fostering experiments of wild-type pups with Nod2e/e pups, which then acquired altered cutaneous bacteria and delayed healing.

To confirm whether Pseudomonas species directly impair wound healing, wild-type mice were infected with Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms and, akin to Nod2e/e mice, were found to exhibit a significant delay in wound repair.

Using a NOD2 null murine model, we show fundamental insights into the role of the innate host response in modulating skin bacteria, with direct effects on tissue repair.RESULTS Nod2-deficient mice have an altered skin microbiome To investigate the role of the PRR Nod2 in the skin, we used the murine Nod2e/e model.

P. aeruginosa-infected mouse model An overnight broth culture of P. aeruginosa (National Collection of Type Cultures 10781) was diluted to turbidity equivalent to 0.5 McFarland standard (optical density ¼ 0.132 at 600 nm) in MuellerHinton broth (Oxoid, Hampshire, UK).
